Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: They organize immediate support and counseling for community members facing a crisis, such as a natural disaster or sudden loss.
Story:
I stared at my phone, my sister’s message glowing on the screen: “Don’t forget, we’re all counting on you to be there for the family trip this weekend. It means a lot to Mom.” I could almost hear her voice, warm but insistent, reminding me how rarely we all get together. My heart ached at the thought of missing the laughter, the shared stories, the sense of belonging that only family brings.

But then my phone buzzed again—this time, a call from the church deacon. “Pastor, several families lost their homes in the flood last night. They need you. We’re organizing emergency shelter and counseling. Can you come right away?” The weight of my congregation’s pain pressed on me. They looked to me for comfort, for guidance, for hope in the darkest moments.

I felt torn in two, the expectations of brother and pastor pulling me in opposite directions. My family needed me to show up, to be present, to celebrate life together. My community needed me to lead, to support, to help them heal. I sat in silence, my heart pounding, caught between love and duty, unsure which call to answer.
